summary: An FBI Miami Division request to the Document Conversion Laboratory (DocLab) for scanning and automation assistance regarding telephone records related to the obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez. The document reveals Rodriguez, Jeffrey Epstein's former house manager, attempted to sell an address book believed to contain contact information for additional underage victims.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.role: Subject of obstruction of justice case, former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the FBI's obstruction of justice investigation. He was Epstein's former house manager and butler who came into possession of and attempted to sell an address book believed to contain names of additional underage victims.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Subject of a child prostitution case
persons.context: Referenced as the subject of a child prostitution case for whom Rodriguez worked. The address book Rodriguez possessed is believed to contain names of his additional underage victims.

connections.description: Rodriguez was the former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein.

Rodriguez possessed an address book believed to contain information on Epstein's underage victims and attempted to sell it rather than provide it to authorities, obstructing the investigation into Epstein.

events.title: FBI opens obstruction case against Rodriguez
events.description: Miami Division opened an obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez.

events.title: Telephone records timeframe
events.description: Telephone records generated between September 1, 2001, and the present (June 2010) are prioritized for processing in the investigation.

events.title: Rodriguez attempts to sell address book
events.description: Alfredo Rodriguez attempted to sell an address book containing names and numbers of potential underage victims to an Undercover Employee (UCE), rather than turning it over to law enforcement or attorneys in response to federal subpoenas.

keyFacts: Alfredo Rodriguez, Jeffrey Epstein's former house manager and butler, was the subject of an FBI obstruction of justice case opened in October 2009.
Rodriguez came into possession of an address book believed to contain names and telephone numbers of additional, previously unknown underage victims of Jeffrey Epstein.
Rodriguez attempted to sell this address book to an Undercover Employee (UCE) instead of complying with federal subpoenas to turn it over to law enforcement or attorneys.
The FBI was processing telephone records (target number 323-666-9942) from the address book, believed to belong to Epstein, his associates, or potential underage victims.

The document is a formal FBI request for the Document Conversion Laboratory to scan and automate these telephone records for incorporation into the Bureau's Telephone Application (TA) investigative database.
